levels.name: Ad Hoc
levels.description: Processes are informal and reactive. Success depends on individual heroics.
indicators: No documented engineering processes
Incident response is chaotic with no runbooks or rotation
No career framework or leveling guide exists
Hiring is ad hoc with no consistent bar or rubric
Deployments are manual and high-risk
recommendedActions: Establish basic on-call rotation with escalation paths
Create hiring rubric for top 2 roles
Implement weekly team standup and retrospectives
Document the top 5 most critical runbooks
Define a minimal deploy checklist

levels.name: Emerging
levels.description: Some processes exist but are inconsistently applied. Pockets of good practice depend on specific managers.
indicators: Basic processes exist but vary across teams
Some teams have on-call rotations, others do not
Career ladder exists on paper but is not calibrated
Hiring loops exist but interviewers are not trained
Retrospectives happen sporadically with no follow-through
Metrics are collected but rarely reviewed or acted upon
recommendedActions: Standardize incident severity definitions across all teams
Train all hiring managers on structured interviewing
Run first org-wide calibration session for performance reviews
Establish a shared engineering metrics dashboard
Create onboarding checklist with 30/60/90-day milestones

levels.name: Defined
levels.description: Consistent processes are documented, communicated, and followed across the organization. Roles and expectations are clear.
indicators: Engineering handbook is published and maintained
All teams follow a consistent SDLC with defined quality gates
Career framework is calibrated and used in promotion decisions
Incident response has defined severity levels, roles, and SLAs
Cross-functional planning cadence is established (quarterly or similar)
Security and compliance requirements are documented and tracked
recommendedActions: Introduce architecture review process for major changes
Implement cross-team dependency tracking and communication
Begin measuring DORA metrics consistently
Establish formal mentorship or coaching program for EMs
Create resource allocation model tied to strategic priorities

levels.name: Managed
levels.description: Processes are measured, data-driven, and continuously improved. Leadership decisions are informed by metrics and feedback loops.
indicators: Engineering metrics are reviewed regularly and drive decisions
Talent reviews and succession planning are formalized
Cross-team dependencies are actively managed with clear owners
Resource allocation follows a transparent framework tied to OKRs
Post-incident reviews consistently produce systemic improvements
Security posture is proactively monitored with vulnerability SLAs
recommendedActions: Introduce leading indicators alongside lagging metrics
Build internal leadership development program for senior ICs and EMs
Establish tech radar or technology governance process
Run annual organizational health survey with action plans
Implement portfolio-level investment tracking across teams

levels.name: Optimizing
levels.description: The organization continuously experiments, learns, and adapts. Engineering leadership is a strategic differentiator.
indicators: Teams proactively experiment with process improvements
Leadership pipeline produces ready-now candidates for critical roles
Engineering strategy is visibly tied to business outcomes
Culture of psychological safety enables candid upward feedback
Failure is treated as a learning signal, not a blame event
Cross-org initiatives are self-organizing with minimal top-down coordination
recommendedActions: Publish internal case studies of successful org changes
Mentor other departments on operational excellence practices
Contribute to industry communities and open-source leadership frameworks
Run chaos engineering exercises for organizational resilience
Establish innovation time or internal incubator programs
